body:
### Problem

I can't reproduce this on other Rust projects or standalone Rust files but I'm getting the following error when I have just one double quote `"` in an `error!();`. It completely crashes Neovim.

```
vim: lib/src/parser.c:1474: ts_parser__handle_error: Assertion `did_merge` failed.
```

I can't find that path anywhere in this repo nor in [the TS grammar for Rust](https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter-rust).

Here's my TS config:
```lua
require('nvim-treesitter.configs').setup({["highlight"] = {["enable"] = true}})
```

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/120189068/245c1e3e-0232-4461-a909-8d8bbdaa1b29



### Steps to reproduce

Couldn't find any way to reproduce this.

Stacktrace:
```
        Signal: 6 (ABRT)
       Message: Process 75444 (nvim) of user 1001 dumped core.
                
                Module comment.so without build-id.
                Module libstdc++.so.6 without build-id.
                Module rust.so without build-id.
                Module libgcc_s.so.1 without build-id.
                Module libluajit-5.1.so.2 without build-id.
                Module libunibilium.so.4 without build-id.
                Module libtree-sitter.so.0 without build-id.
                Module libmsgpack-c.so.2 without build-id.
                Module libvterm.so.0 without build-id.
                Module libtermkey.so.1 without build-id.
                Module libluv.so.1 without build-id.
                Stack trace of thread 75444:
                #0  0x00007f65cfc0107c __pthread_kill_implementation (libc.so.6 + 0x8d07c)
                #1  0x00007f65cfbb1e06 raise (libc.so.6 + 0x3de06)
                #2  0x00007f65cfb9a8f5 abort (libc.so.6 + 0x268f5)
                #3  0x00007f65cfb9a819 __assert_fail_base.cold (libc.so.6 + 0x26819)
                #4  0x00007f65cfbaa686 __assert_fail (libc.so.6 + 0x36686)
                #5  0x00007f65cff3b903 ts_parser_parse (libtree-sitter.so.0 + 0x13903)
                #6  0x00000000005c1b95 parser_parse (nvim + 0x1c1b95)
                #7  0x00007f65cfe8fa36 n/a (libluajit-5.1.so.2 + 0xba36)
                #8  0x00007f65cfeeaafc lua_pcall (libluajit-5.1.so.2 + 0x66afc)
                #9  0x00000000005af7c8 nlua_pcall.lto_priv.0 (nvim + 0x1af7c8)
                #10 0x00000000005befbc nlua_call_ref (nvim + 0x1befbc)
                #11 0x000000000074fdb4 decor_provider_invoke.constprop.0 (nvim + 0x34fdb4)
                #12 0x00000000004caae4 decor_providers_invoke_buf (nvim + 0xcaae4)
                #13 0x00000000004e7c34 update_screen (nvim + 0xe7c34)
                #14 0x000000000060be62 normal_check.lto_priv.0 (nvim + 0x20be62)
                #15 0x00000000006d4f6e state_enter (nvim + 0x2d4f6e)
                #16 0x000000000060b974 normal_enter (nvim + 0x20b974)
                #17 0x0000000000455310 main (nvim + 0x55310)
                #18 0x00007f65cfb9c0ce __libc_start_call_main (libc.so.6 + 0x280ce)
                #19 0x00007f65cfb9c189 __libc_start_main@@GLIBC_2.34 (libc.so.6 + 0x28189)
                #20 0x0000000000457415 _start (nvim + 0x57415)
                
                Stack trace of thread 75446:
                #0  0x0000000000000000 n/a (n/a + 0x0)
                ELF object binary architecture: AMD x86-64
```

### Expected behavior

I expected that it wouldn't crash Neovim completely.

Are tree-sitter grammars parsed in-process with no separation?

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.9.5 Build type: Release

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

Vim doesn't have native TS support and I can't reproduce the issue

### Operating system/version

NixOS unstable

### Terminal name/version

kitty 0.33.1

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-kitty

### Installation

Nix/[Nixvim](https://nix-community.github.io/nixvim/user-guide/install.html)

comment_data.body: Oh I searched just for `ts_parser_handle_error` without the double underscores. Thanks!

labels.description: issues that are closed as duplicates of other issues
labels.name: closed:duplicate

title: ts_parser__handle_error
